part.line: Madame Soleil, I believe you are familiar with the exterior of our facilities.
I heard some rowdy twenty-something came along and singed the banners.
Surely no issue if flags represent not your passions.
part.narration: The Demomen glare at Soleil. Soleil clutches Nozomi's hand. The Demomen continue.
part.line: Welcome to the present, the future, the Pride and Glory of the Japanese game industry.
Enjoy the tour of our wonderful facilities.
Remember:
Your response. Immediately.
part.narration: All enter the building.

Transparent light emitting diode monitors are all neatly tiled amongst the space's walls. Same-landed employes in straight-pressed suits light-march across the harshly shining stark-white floors. Abysses of stories of servers whir in purposeless orchestration.
part.line: We have a single, unified facility where all studios and equipment are one.
Next, let us view the outsourcing facility.
part.narration: The Demomen, Soleil, and Nozomi enter a glass elevator. The elevator rises to the center area of the facility. Before the tour-guides and tour-takers — people on fours creep cross the floor. Those on break are too tired to eat. Those on work are too weary to type. Those clocking out are ready to weep.
part.line: They're — so young — these —
These are interns!
part.narration: The Demomen laugh. Computational smokes tarnish the already-thin air. A Draft comes in and loudly blows the smog and tar about. One Demoman puts his sole to an intern's struggling brow.
part.line: Survival of the fittest.
At The Group, all workers earn their positions.
part.narration: The Demomen glare at Soleil. Soleil scoffs. The Demomen continue.
part.line: And if they don't make it, what to them do you do?
It's not what we do. It's what they do.
part.narration: A computer monitor flies past Soleil's face. The monitor slams against a desk. Soleil gasps. An intern begins his Dash.Slow motion. Soleil looks at the Player and points at the Dasher. The Player can direct Soleil to chase him. Soleil runs as far as the Player will take her. Realize: He is faster than She.

choice.narration: Soleil rushes at the Dasher, grabs at the Dasher, reaches for the Dasher. Zoom out.Bare and naked at the end of the line is a hole where used to be a window. The Dasher leaps. At the balcony Soleil thumps. Hand loose and tense and all a-thrust, she screams over the edge.

Soleil hesitates. In mid-stride she slips and then drops. Every stomp of the Dasher's run ripples the ground.Zoom out slowly to keep Dasher in view at all times.Bare and naked at the end of the line is a hole where used to be a window. The Dasher leaps. At the floor Soleil thumps. Hand loose and tense and all a-thrust, she screams across the ground.

part.narration: Soleil weeps and wails and The Demomen drag her by the feet back towards that oh-so-beautiful elevator as the clumps about her lashes remain unaffected by her tears and Nozomi kneels down next to her and holds her tight. Soleil yells:
part.line: Stop hiring interns!
They can't handle the load! You can't keep them here!
If interns cannot hold their lunch, you cannot hold your breath.
part.narration: Soleil puffs.
part.line: Next, we will visit our History Center.
History Center?
Yes, for without record of our legacy, we have nothing.
Decades of stagnation, a "legacy."
More of a legacy than your "Sonic Adventure Portable," eh Hasegawa?
part.narration: Nozomi folds her arms. The elevator reaches its destination. All exit.Zoom out. More transparent monitors. Now, they litter not only the walls but the walkways and the air and the floor.
part.line: Behold; this is home to four decades of digitized commit logs.
part.narration: A Demoman presses the button. The screens all change to a font monospaced. Their interpretation of the History of Video Games is shown. Soleil observes the ones she can read:
part.line: 1983. gave jump-man a friend. -- s. miyamoto
1985. put princess far away. -- t. tezuka
1986. made kunio move up and down too. -- y. kishimoto
1986. made battles random -- y. horii
1987. screw those guys, our random battles are better!!! -- h. sakaguchi
1995. changed warrior hair color to blonde. video cutscenes hard to change. hope u dont mind. -- t. nomura
This is remarkable.
part.narration: The Demomen jump up and down.
part.line: We also have video documentation of internal and external developer activity.
part.narration: A Demoman presses the button. The screens all change to video players. Spontaneous camerawork is shown.The screen the Player moves Soleil closest to is the one that will be heard.

condition.narration: Soleil stands at the screen labeled "group_init:"
A sales representative, newspaper in hand, slams the table.
condition.line: Parisian-Nagoyan Network's "Flashback Fourth Dimension —"
Receives Famitsu Magazine's fourth Perfect Score!
They didn't even pay them off!
Parisian-Nagoyan Network's "Flashback Fourth Dimension —"
Outsells Wind Waker!
They don't even have Zelda's legacy!
condition.narration: A market analyst rubs his chin.
condition.line: Well, they've essentially become a more powerful corporate force than we.
More powerful? We're Nintendo!
Yes, but The PNN is Panasonic and Fujitsu and Canon and Delphine and Adeline and Clickteam—
That's it!
The PNN is a network of individuals.
So to beat them, we must become a single powerful force: a Group.

condition.narration: Soleil stands at the screen labeled "old_pnn_sortie:"
The people on screen, all different-landed, flip out their cellphones.
condition.line: This land has some strange mobile phones.
condition.narration: The designer operating the camera laughs.
condition.line: Still though, I bet they're pretty good for gaming.
At this point, a mobile phone game is all that's in the budget.
The damn Group's got us at the finale at the start of the play.
After this game is where we must take our Leave.
Hey, that's a good idea for a name:
La Sortie.
La Sortie des Usines Jeux Ã Lyon.

condition.narration: Soleil stands at the screen labeled "group_plan:"
A sales representative, newspaper in hand, slams the table.
condition.line: Parisian-Nagoyan Network's "La Sortie—"
Receives Famitsu Magazine's eighth Perfect Score!
Parisian-Nagoyan Network's "La Sortie—
Outsells Metal Gear Solid 4!
condition.narration: The sales representative sighs. The analyst smirks.
condition.line: Gentlemen.
Let's gun 'em down.

part.narration: All the screens go blank.
part.line: Good stuff, huh?
Let's move on to The Group's greatest creation.
part.narration: The Demomen rush back into the elevator. Soleil and Nozomi walk back in.

The Demomen press a button. The elevator flies. Hundreds of lights fly by. Through the tight, tight glass permeate the sounds of construction. Through the greenhouse magnifies the sun. The elevator halts. Soleil stumbles. The Demomen stay arms a-fold.
part.line: Behold.
part.narration: The elevator opens.Zoom out extremely far.

Before all is a hulking, steaming, buzzing, fizzling machine. The wires sprawl across the entirety of the roof, half extending back to the abyss of mounted servers below. Fans make to dance the un-natural heat waves. Status lights out-brighten the sun. This is no place for humanity.
part.line: All you see before you,
Concept art, Narrative fragments, Musical compositions,
Design documents, Source code, Manuals, Advertisement,
Interviews, Emails, Full Motion Video Cutscenes —
Is computer generated.
part.narration: Soleil quivers. The Demomen continue.
part.line: Madame Soleil, what you see before you is the greatest invention in the history of video games.
The Brain of Gotanda, the Guitar of Meguro, the Life of Miyamoto,
All condensed into a single machine.
A machine with hundreds of terabytes of random access memory.
A machine with the graphical capability of twenty Pixars.
A machine that, independent of The Group's control, will procedurally generate a blockbuster.
Behold:
RPG Maker 2012.
part.narration: By the collar Soleil grabs a Demoman.
part.line: This is wrong, this is wrong!
Video games are made by People!
We are people.
You're a Corporation!
Will you become one with this Corporation?
part.narration: Madame Soleil drops the man to the ground. She trudges to a nearby server rack. She slumps upon it. Zoom out slowly regardless of interaction. Player can move Soleil at any time.Nozomi stares at her. The Demoman dance and holler. The surveillance cameras zoom in and out on Soleil. The server fans blow Soleil's hair. She stares over the building's edge. Soleil smiles and laughs the dissonant whirs away:
A Judge bangs his gavel.
part.line: I hereby declare the defendant, Mademoiselle Yuki Soleil-Takeshi —
Innocent!
part.narration: Two Policemen knock their glasses against Soleil's.
part.line: A vodka lover, huh! And more sober than we after a few.
part.narration: He holds his keys out.
part.line: Can you drive us home?
part.narration: The Prime Minister shakes hands with Soleil.
part.line: How does it feel, being this land's first legally recognized same-sex spouse — Madame?
part.narration: NoLifeQueen kisses Soleil on the cheek!
part.line: Yeah, Madame! How does it feel to be a goddamned sellout?
How do you like retreating to the fake when you need to deal with the real?
How do you like not being alive?
part.narration: The Group! Headquarters! Roof! RPG Maker 2012! Offer! Legal Action! Response — — —
part.line: No!
No!
No!
part.narration: Soleil laughs.She urges the Player to the elevator. It's time to leave.
The Demomen stop dancing.
Nozomi clasps her hands together and grins.
Soleil and Nozomi enter the elevator. Soleil and Nozomi descend to the first floor. Soleil and Nozomi exit the building.
